value.string: Wedding Blog: Guests That Don't RSVP!

Slice.ca is your ultimate tool for wedding planning advice and help with sticky situations, so here is my advice on a frustrating wedding planning issue.   When I was planning my own wedding, everything seemed perfect and fun, until it was time to plan the seating arrangements.  What is it with guests who don?t RSVP?  Are they assuming that you know they are coming, or do they just don?t realize that the RSVP information is there for a reason???   Is this sounding like you?  I have seen this happen probably with over 90% of my brides.  Everything is in place, but are those final non-repliers coming or not?  Do they realize that the entire seating arrangement is on hold until you know exactly who and how many people are coming?  Besides the seating arrangements, there are suppliers that need a final head count.  Your caterer needs to know the number of meals for adults and kids, your florist needs to know the final count for centerpieces, you need to have your place cards printed and you need to know how many wedding favors to order!   Before you write off any friends or family, take a deep breath.   Here?s the thing, well-intentioned friends and loved ones do forget and assume that you already know that they are coming.  Your dear aunt who has been congratulating you for months may think that you already put her on the confirmed list, and doesn?t need to formally reply.  Some older relatives may not feel the need to RSVP, as it is a given that they will be attending.   Keep in mind as well, that mail sometimes does get lost in transit.   When this does happen, it takes usually up to 3 weeks until you discover this.  Also, you may have addressed the invitation to an old address.  Sounds like a lame excuse, but believe me, it happens.   People move all the time and especially if it is not someone that you keep in constant contact with, this may be very likely.   The only solution to this situation is to call, but who will do this? If they are close friends of yours and you are comfortable with calling, you can call, but remember to be polite, and ask them first, if they received the invitation.  You may be relieved to find out that you did send the invitation to an old address or the wrong address.  You can tell them how much their presence would mean to you, but also understand if they cannot make it for whatever reason.   Also, you don?t have to call everyone yourself.  Split these call duties.  If some of these non-replying guests are from your fiance?s group or family, give him that list to tackle.  If it is an old friend or distant relative of your mom or dad?s, it is okay to have them call these people.   Please whatever you do?  Never email or text guests.  This is a wedding and the RSVP should be treated with as much formality as the day itself.   Lastly, to do your best to prevent all this from happening, include in the RSVP information, not only the RSVP  reply card, but make sure there is sufficient postage and also include a telephone number.  An extra security?.  Include an RSVP button on your wedding website.  GOOD LUCK!!   Written by Rita Wong, Rita Wong Events http://www.ritawongevents.com Rita Wong is a wedding and events planner and owner of Rita Wong Events. Based in Montreal, Rita also plans many weddings every year for brides living in Toronto and abroad. She is a dedicated follower of new trends and her goal is to give each bride a wedding that is fresh, unique, and a personal reflection of who they are. She now shares her professional insights with slice.ca.
